XmlWorldData.name: Filter Tutorial
XmlWorldData.description: This tutorial will show you how to use filters.
XmlWorldData.creator: scoy

Step.GamepadText:
This tutorial will teach you how to use Filters in your programming. Filters allow you to be more specific about the things that your character senses.
Let's start with a simple case.

Step.GamepadText:
We will start with a world that already has some objects in it. The world contains a Kodu <kodu> and several apples <apple> and rocks <rock>.
We're going to program Kodu <kodu> to move toward anything he sees.

Step.GamepadText: On the first row move the pencil cursor to the plus sign next to WHEN then press <a> to add <sensor.eyes>
Step.MouseText: On the first row click on the plus sign next to WHEN and add <sensor.eyes>
Step.TouchText: On the first row tap on the plus sign next to WHEN and add <sensor.eyes>

Step.GamepadText: Now move the pencil cursor to the right of DO and add <actuator.movement> When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes> DO <actuator.movement>
Step.MouseText: Now click on the plus sign to the right of DO and add <actuator.movement> When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes> DO <actuator.movement>
Step.TouchText: Now tap on the plus sign to the right of DO and add <actuator.movement> When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes> DO <actuator.movement>

Step.GamepadText: At the plus next to <actuator.movement> add <selector.towardclosest> When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes> DO <actuator.movement><selector.towardclosest>
Step.MouseText: At the plus next to <actuator.movement> add <selector.towardclosest> When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes> DO <actuator.movement><selector.towardclosest>
Step.TouchText: At the plus next to <actuator.movement> add <selector.towardclosest> When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes> DO <actuator.movement><selector.towardclosest>

Step.GamepadText: Okay, now we can play the game and see what happens.
Step.MouseText: Okay, now we can play the game and see what happens.
Step.TouchText: Okay, now we can play the game and see what happens.

Step.GamepadText:
Okay, Kodu <kodu> did just what we told him. He went to the nearest object which happens to be a rock <rock>. But what if we want him to go to an apple <apple> instead? This is where we can use a Filter to specify what we want him to look for.
Let's go back to the editor and add an apple filter to Kodu's programming so he just looks for apples <apple>.

Let's go back to the editor and add an apple filter to Kodu's programming so he just looks for apples <apple>.

Okay, Kodu <kodu> did just what we told him. He went to the nearest object which happens to be a rock <rock>. But what if we want him to go to an apple <apple> instead? This is where we can use a Filter to specify what we want him to look for.
Let's go back to the editor and add an apple filter to Kodu's programming so he just looks for apples <apple>.

Step.GamepadText: In the space next to the sight sensor <sensor.eyes> add <filter.fruit> The apple can be found in the objects group <group.objects>. When done you should have WHEN <sensor.eyes><filter.fruit> DO <actuator.movement><selector.towardclosest>

Step.GamepadText: Okay, now we can play the game again and see what happens.

Step.GamepadText:
Yeah! Kodu <kodu> found the apple <apple>. Using filters we can be even more specific than that. Notice that the apple <apple> Kodu <kodu>went to was green.
Let's add another filter so Kodu <kodu> only looks for red apples <apple>.
